title: Hey All, I'm Riot Belquin, part of the Riot OCE Esports Team - Ask me anything!
body:
Hey Summoners!

My name is Chris Schubert and I work in the Esports team in Riot OCE - my focus is on helping the local scene grow through our teams development and the ways fans can show their 'colours' and engage with their favourite players/teams. I'm here to help create a long term sustainable model for the OPL and Esports in OCE. We love our sport in this region, and I want us to be able to show it!

{{summoner:4}} **ASK ME ANYTHING! I'll be around for a few hours answering questions.**{{summoner:4}} 


**Career Background**
A little bit about my background - I've been with Riot for about 7 months now, before that I worked in traditional sports (specifically with a lower tier Rugby League team). During that time I completed my MBA, explored options of going into the corporate world, but decided that my passion and love for gaming was the path I wanted to go down. I decided that I wanted to follow my passion and make a difference in Esports and League of Legends in Oceania.

**My Gaming History**
My love of gaming started as a child with Snes, N64 which I loved Mario Kart, Super Smash Brothers. Once I got to high school, my vices became Counter Strike - playing in a LAN cafe after school every Friday, as well as Warcraft 3 - Frozen Throne (Dota allstars, Footy Wars WOOOOOH!), Natural Selection. I had a fairly long stretch after that of playing World of Warcraft - starting off with Raiding, but then mostly Arenas. I achieved Gladiator rank 4 times on a number of classes and was a fairly high rated Aussie player (250ms wtf). When I started working full-time, I transitioned back to just playing Dota, then HON, then League and Dota 2 and then League of Legends again. Nowadays I'm playing some Player Unknowns: Battlegrounds, Diablo, Hots, CS:GO and still loving my League of Legends.

**Let's Talk League**
I'm a Mid/ADC main - My favourite Champions are Orianna, Anivia and Syndra for mid and Ezreal/Caitlyn in the bot lane. I do sometimes like to have a crack at LeBlanc mid and Lucian adc, but they're too mechanical for me haha  {{summoner:3}} 

Enough about me - tell me about you guys, or throw any questions you have at me :)

Ask me anything!

Hey LostStarDust - I just wrote an epic detailed response then hit the back button on my mouse {{summoner:3}}.

So the next major project we are all super excited about is [League of Legends: League of Origin ](http://oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/esports/esports-event/introducing-league-legends-league-origin). I'm so keen to see the state vs state rivalries coming out and see so many passionate fans getting behind their state. I'm also looking forward to some ferocious gameplay as the best of each state does fights hard for the win! 

Philosophically, the next big steps we want to work on is facilitating our players/fans coming together for social situations around our game. I'm really not sure what this will look like as of right now but we recognise its importance.

I've definitely heard your and other players feedback about the OCS visibility and definitely want to work on providing more access to the grass roots League of Legends - being the OCS, OOL and even community tournaments. It definitely was disappointing though in split 1 and we will do better :)

Cheers

Hey Jason, 

Thanks for the questions. In regards to #1 - I am hugely un-technical when it comes to Video and Broadcast. What I would say is that there's definitely opportunities for community created Webseries from a teams perspective and I think its a huge area for growth that our players would love. For the production/broadcast tech - I'm gonna bring in the big guns - Riot Perigan who is the OPL producer and has the expertise on these matters in our office.

For #2 - If we were to attend conventions again, the primary purpose would not be to sell merchandise. Personally I am completely on board with supporting the teams in selling their merchandise to help our players express their love for a team, but I'm not sure that attending conventions to do this is the right way - but at OPL related events, of course.

Hey Jason,

As to your first question that's something either myself or Riot Benji could answer and it's actually a really interesting one. Producing a show in 1080p 60 (59.94) is not industry standard for broadcast in Australia and almost all the hardware, though theoretically 1080p capable, is typically run at 1080i and most definitely not at 60 fps. Without hijacking Belquins thread the tl;dr is that we built a studio that combines technologies (broadcast and digital) in order to produce at 1080p 60. CNET did a tour of the studio in split 1 and released a video article which featured some of our broadcast tech that might interest you. 

:)

It's funny, that progressive over interlaced is such a standard for internet based playback with youtube and twitch, but it's still quite common in traditional broadcast.

Hey Mate,

What are your thoughts on the OCE Esports scene?  Do you think it will actually be a competitive player on the world stage?

At this point it seems that the Korea's have taken over the show for quite some time now, if not the Korea's then surely an Asian country in the top tier leagues.

Based on your experience working with Riot and such, what are the things that the OCE need to work on to become a competitive player on the world stage?  Is this objective with different RIOT departments around the world to try and develop the gameplay for different countries?

Also, can the OCE learn anything from the Korea's on the OCE can act and behavior inorder to achieve these goals (if the goal is to develop a completive base in the OCE).

Just to go back to the "Korean's taken over" bit, do you think if the Korean teams dominate the Esports of League may this discourage players around the world that they are no match for the Koreans?

I could use an example such as the NRL where you have the top tier teams who always hover in the top 8 where the rest have been where they are for quite sometime (yes you have the one off's like the Sharks winning the NRL finals for the first time) but majority of the top tier teams would hover in the top 8 or top 4 for years and years.

So coming back to the OCE scene, is it one of those things where the OCE will need years to prepare before they become a competitive top player on the world stage, I fear that how the gaming industry goes many games come and go depending on where the market is (eg Blizzard with Storm of Heroes and others.)

Is it possible to create the foundation within the OCE to start and build of that, which that way the foundation and skills can be transferred to other games depending on how hot the market for what game, in this case it's (League of Legends).

Cheers.

Hey Macktheboloz,

Really good questions - definitely things we also grapple with on a day to day basis - we would love the OCE region to be internationally competitive and essentially that is one of the things we aim to contribute to in how we invest in setting up the scene. 

To me - similarly to the NRL, the best equipped teams with the best infrastructure (coaching, training regime, analysts, psychologists, boot camps, international experience etc), always manage to be competitive. What we are trying to focus on is helping our Esports teams partner up with commercial/business partners to help them commercialise in order to earn more money to then invest into their performance through the infrastructural things I mentioned before.

I believe we are still years behind Korea - they have had Esports for literally 10-15 years before anywhere else in the world, they have Esports TV channels, fibre to every home etc. What we do have is the advantage of learning from what they have done in order to catch up more quickly. We have our sporting codes being able to see the success of Esports in Korea, and having a great crossover with things like Sports Psychologists, High Performance Coaches, Nutritionists etc which are all relevant in Esports training too.

We want League of Legends to become a sport - we don't want it to be like World of Warcraft arena as a sub part of a larger game with a small following, we want to set up League of Legends Esports to be an enduring sport played for many many years to come. This is well aligned with Riot's development - seeing how much the game has grown and developed year on year is staggering and I believe that is a critical part of remaining relevant, up to date and transcending the 'come and go' style of games.

Thanks a lot for the questions and comments though - I love thinking about and trying to think how best we can solve these types of challenges :)

Greetings Belquin, nice to meet you! 

Today I have four questions for you, two a bit more serious in regards to it being about your work, two just more fun things about gaming. (I feel like this is becoming a trend for me on these AMAs... xD )

* **1:** Coming from working in traditional sports to eSports I understand that there would be quite a lot of crossover as far as the skills that you have learned, but what would you say were your key learnings from your experience in traditional sports that helps you in your job today?


* **2:** You mentioned that your main focus is helping the local scene grow. Now my question is do you have any advice for people in the community that want to run their own events to help the OCE scene grow?


* **3:** Who was your 'go-to' character in smash brothers? 


* **4:** I am going to be flying down for League of Origin (Super hyped to come watch it!) but what 'team' or 'state' are you going for?

Thankyou!

~Elam

Hey Elam - I remember meeting you down at Pax late last year, you are a designer right? :) 

4. I'm a new south welshman so will be going for the NSW team! I'm also super hyped.

3. My go-to was Captain Falcon - I loved how fast he was and his backwards kick was fairly strong.

2. Good question, I think there's definitely a lot of opportunities to help the OCE scene. Content about the league, the play, the players, the team is always a really good one that I love watching/reading. Creating and running community tournaments is another great way - there are a number of amateur level tournaments run by the community that is a great way to help build up the scene. Another way could be to get involved with University Clubs and help them coordinate tournaments between and within them. You could line up an OPL team to run training camps for younger players in the offseason. I'm sure there's a million other ways, but I hope these are a start :)

1. I'd say the scaling and strategic planning skills - I was able to see the results of some really good scaling where we went from 1 overly expensive team and scaled up to 4 different grades, as well as results of sticking to a clearly defined strategy and ending up in a position where we delivered on our expectations and were building something really great. Insights into the emotional / fanatical nature of fans too is something that's important for me in my job today.

Thanks for the questions

Thanks for the responses! Its really interesting to learn about some of the skills you picked up from previously working in sports, along with your advice for those who want to help grow the OCE scene I will keep those in mind. 

I am writing a post at the moment for people wanting to get into the OCE eSports scene and lend a hand. I would love to get to your thoughts and feedback on it before I post it if you wouldn't mind? Would really appreciate your input for anything I should add or etc.

Hi Belquin,

There's been news of the AFL looking to branch into eSports and host an event at Etihad Stadium later this year.

Given your experience in eSports and traditional sports, do you think mixing them is feasible and an opportunity for future growth?

Also is there anything in the works / could there be? I for one would be so keen to get behind some stadium eSports action!

Mcteamster

Hey McTeamster,

Yeah! I've definitely been following the interest around Esports from Traditional Sports. I definitely think there is a strong crossover with Traditional Sports and Esports and a future that involves large games with live audiences (Etihad is HUGE and would be an amazing Coup if we could fill that up haha!) But then again, we have Worlds being held in China in the Birds Nest (90,000 capacity) this year, so it would definitely be possible (assuming it sells out!)

Although I'm a huge Sports fan (go the Penrith Panthers! although not so much this season :() - I also have a lot of friends where Esports is their Sport, they don't watch anything else but follow their team throughout the season on Twitch. I think Esports fans are the same as Sports fans, except instead of having physical fitness and contact, we have strategic thinking, micro execution, macro execution, teamwork and communication. I also think there's some synergies for traditional sports sponsors in having their brand associated with an OPL team and building an affinity with the next generation of fans!

I don't want to commit that we will have an Etihad stadium filled by later this year - but we definitely see a demand and passion for stadium games and will work out what the right way is for us to approach it. IEM atmosphere was amazing and showed that OCE is definitely ready to get out and support a large scale Esports event with international teams!!

Thanks for the question, you and I definitely have similar interests and excitement for the future :)
